user_error_text: I see 'Faulty RAM stick' and the system is unstable.
symptoms: Symptoms: Faulty RAM stick. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: RAM / Memory Errors.
cause: Faulty RAM modules, incorrect timings/voltage, or slot issues causing memory errors.
step_1: Power off and unplug the PC, then carefully remove and reseat RAM sticks.
step_2: Try one RAM stick at a time to identify a faulty module.
step_3: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) or MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_4: Check BIOS for correct memory settings; disable XMP/overclocking to test stability.
step_5: Replace the failing RAM module if diagnostics report errors.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Faulty RAM stick - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: I see 'Webcam not detected' and the system is unstable.
symptoms: Symptoms: Webcam not detected. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Peripheral & External Hardware Failures.
cause: External device fault or short causing system instability or boot problems.
step_1: Disconnect external devices one-by-one and check if issue stops to identify the faulty peripheral.
step_2: Try the device on another system to confirm if it is defective.
step_3: Update peripheral drivers and firmware from the manufacturer's site.
step_4: Use a powered USB hub for devices that need extra power.
step_5: Replace the peripheral if it causes repeated system instability.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Webcam not detected - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: Loose cables causing no boot happens randomly and causes crashes.
symptoms: Symptoms: Loose cables causing no boot. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Motherboard Errors.
cause: Faulty motherboard components, damaged traces, or failed POST due to VRM or chipset faults.
step_1: Power down, unplug, and inspect motherboard for visible damage or bulging caps.
step_2: Clear CMOS by removing CMOS battery or using jumper to reset BIOS settings.
step_3: Reseat CPU, RAM, and power connectors; ensure no standoffs short the board.
step_4: Listen for beep codes and consult manual to interpret POST errors.
step_5: If board is faulty, backup data and replace the motherboard.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Loose cables causing no boot - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

category: Hard Drive / SSD / Storage Device Errors
user_error_text: After recent changes I now experience: Disk not detected.
symptoms: Symptoms: Disk not detected. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Hard Drive / SSD / Storage Device Errors.
cause: Failing storage device, bad sectors, or controller issues causing read/write errors.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive if accessible.
step_2: Run SMART check using vendor tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to inspect drive health.
step_3: Run chkdsk on the affected drive: `chkdsk D: /f /r` (replace D: as needed).
step_4: Try connecting the drive to another port or PC to verify detection.
step_5: If SMART indicates failure, replace the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Disk not detected - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: Low-voltage instability - my PC behaves oddly and I need help.
symptoms: Symptoms: Low-voltage instability. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Power Supply Unit (PSU) Errors.
cause: Unstable or insufficient power delivery from the power supply affecting system stability.
step_1: Check all power cables (24-pin, 8-pin) are fully connected to motherboard and GPU.
step_2: Try a different known-good power outlet and avoid overloaded power strips.
step_3: If possible, test with a spare PSU or a PSU tester to verify voltages.
step_4: Do not continue using a PSU that emits burning smells—replace immediately.
step_5: Ensure PSU wattage is sufficient for your components; upgrade if underpowered.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Low-voltage instability - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

step_2: Clear CMOS by removing CMOS battery or using jumper to reset BIOS settings.
step_3: Reseat CPU, RAM, and power connectors; ensure no standoffs short the board.
step_4: Listen for beep codes and consult manual to interpret POST errors.
step_5: If board is faulty, backup data and replace the motherboard.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Damaged VRM / power delivery - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT crash happens randomly and causes crashes.
symptoms: Symptoms: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT crash. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: RAM / Memory Errors.
cause: Faulty RAM modules, incorrect timings/voltage, or slot issues causing memory errors.
step_1: Power off and unplug the PC, then carefully remove and reseat RAM sticks.
step_2: Try one RAM stick at a time to identify a faulty module.
step_3: Run Windows Memory Diagnostic (mdsched.exe) or MemTest86 for extended testing.
step_4: Check BIOS for correct memory settings; disable XMP/overclocking to test stability.
step_5: Replace the failing RAM module if diagnostics report errors.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: MEMORY_MANAGEMENT crash - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: GPU fan not spinning - my PC behaves oddly and I need help.
symptoms: Symptoms: GPU fan not spinning. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Cooling System Errors.
cause: Failed fans, dried thermal paste, clogged heatsinks leading to thermal throttling or shutdowns.
step_1: Inspect and clean dust from fans and heatsinks; ensure fans spin freely.
step_2: Reapply thermal paste on CPU if it is older than 2–3 years.
step_3: Ensure proper case airflow: intake at front, exhaust at rear/top.
step_4: Replace failed fans and check fan headers and cables for power.
step_5: Consider upgrading cooler if temperatures remain high under load.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: GPU fan not spinning - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: My computer reports: Bent CPU pins — how to fix?
symptoms: Symptoms: Bent CPU pins. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: CPU / Processor Errors.
cause: CPU thermal issues, insufficient cooling, or motherboard/VRM instability.
step_1: Check CPU cooler mounting and ensure fan(s) spin at boot.
step_2: Reset BIOS to defaults and disable overclocking/XMP profiles.
step_3: Monitor CPU temperatures in BIOS or with a tool; replace thermal paste if needed.
step_4: Run a short CPU stress test to check for throttling or errors.
step_5: If CPU faults persist, consult hardware support—consider replacing CPU/motherboard.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Bent CPU pins - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

category: Hard Drive / SSD / Storage Device Errors
user_error_text: After recent changes I now experience: Clicking HDD noise.
symptoms: Symptoms: Clicking HDD noise. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Hard Drive / SSD / Storage Device Errors.
cause: Failing storage device, bad sectors, or controller issues causing read/write errors.
step_1: Backup important data immediately to an external drive if accessible.
step_2: Run SMART check using vendor tools (CrystalDiskInfo) to inspect drive health.
step_3: Run chkdsk on the affected drive: `chkdsk D: /f /r` (replace D: as needed).
step_4: Try connecting the drive to another port or PC to verify detection.
step_5: If SMART indicates failure, replace the drive and restore data from backup.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Clicking HDD noise - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

cause: CPU thermal issues, insufficient cooling, or motherboard/VRM instability.
step_1: Check CPU cooler mounting and ensure fan(s) spin at boot.
step_2: Reset BIOS to defaults and disable overclocking/XMP profiles.
step_3: Monitor CPU temperatures in BIOS or with a tool; replace thermal paste if needed.

user_error_text: My computer reports: PC won't power on — how to fix?
symptoms: Symptoms: PC won't power on. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Power Supply Unit (PSU) Errors.
cause: Unstable or insufficient power delivery from the power supply affecting system stability.
step_1: Check all power cables (24-pin, 8-pin) are fully connected to motherboard and GPU.
step_2: Try a different known-good power outlet and avoid overloaded power strips.
step_3: If possible, test with a spare PSU or a PSU tester to verify voltages.
step_4: Do not continue using a PSU that emits burning smells—replace immediately.
step_5: Ensure PSU wattage is sufficient for your components; upgrade if underpowered.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: PC won't power on - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: My computer reports: CPU overheating -> shutdown — how to fix?
symptoms: Symptoms: CPU overheating -> shutdown. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Overheating & Thermal Failures.
cause: Poor airflow, failed cooling components, or degraded thermal interface causing overheating.
step_1: Check case fans and airflow; clean dust and ensure unobstructed vents.
step_2: Monitor temperatures under load and at idle to identify spikes.
step_3: Reapply thermal paste to CPU/GPU if paste is old or dried.
step_4: Ensure laptop vents are clear and use a cooling pad for laptops.
step_5: If temperatures remain high, upgrade cooling components (better cooler, additional fans).
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: CPU overheating -> shutdown - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

cause: Poor airflow, failed cooling components, or degraded thermal interface causing overheating.
step_1: Check case fans and airflow; clean dust and ensure unobstructed vents.
step_2: Monitor temperatures under load and at idle to identify spikes.
step_3: Reapply thermal paste to CPU/GPU if paste is old or dried.
step_4: Ensure laptop vents are clear and use a cooling pad for laptops.

user_error_text: I see 'Black screen when GPU activates' and the system is unstable.
symptoms: Symptoms: Black screen when GPU activates. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: GPU / Graphics Card Errors.
cause: GPU overheating, driver failure, or power/connectivity issues to the graphics card.
step_1: Ensure GPU power connectors are firmly attached and card is seated in PCIe slot.
step_2: Boot into Safe Mode and reinstall GPU drivers (use DDU for clean uninstall).
step_3: Monitor GPU temperatures and clean dust from heatsink/fans.
step_4: Test with integrated graphics or another GPU to isolate the card.
step_5: If hardware failure confirmed, RMA or replace the GPU.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Black screen when GPU activates - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

error_name: Monitor cable loose causing no display
user_error_text: After recent changes I now experience: Monitor cable loose causing no display.
symptoms: Symptoms: Monitor cable loose causing no display. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Peripheral & External Hardware Failures.
cause: External device fault or short causing system instability or boot problems.
step_1: Disconnect external devices one-by-one and check if issue stops to identify the faulty peripheral.
step_2: Try the device on another system to confirm if it is defective.
step_3: Update peripheral drivers and firmware from the manufacturer's site.
step_4: Use a powered USB hub for devices that need extra power.
step_5: Replace the peripheral if it causes repeated system instability.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Monitor cable loose causing no display - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.

user_error_text: My computer reports: Damaged power connector — how to fix?
symptoms: Symptoms: Damaged power connector. Typically causes instability, crashes, failure to boot, or degraded performance. Category: Cable & Connector Issues.
cause: Loose or damaged cables/connectors causing intermittent device detection or power issues.
step_1: Power down and reseat SATA/HDMI/DisplayPort/PCIe power cables securely.
step_2: Try a different cable to rule out a faulty cable.
step_3: Inspect connectors for bent pins or corrosion and replace if damaged.
step_4: Ensure cables are not pinched and have proper strain relief.
step_5: Use cable ties to avoid accidental unplugging and test again.
verification: System runs stable under normal use and stress tests without reproducing the hardware fault.
log_snippet: Damaged power connector - Hardware diagnostic entry or SMART log recorded.
